greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of partitions of n into parts <= 3 with the property that all parts have distinct multiplicities.
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..500
Doron Zeilberger, Using generatingfunctionology to enumerate distinct-multiplicity partitions.
example: For n=3 the a(3)=2 partitions are {3} and {1,1,1}. Note that {2,1} does not count, as 1 and 2 appear with the same nonzero multiplicity.
program: p m ms _      0 = if m `elem` ms then 0 else 1
| m == 0      = p 1 ms ks' (x - k) + p 0 ms ks x
| m `elem` ms = p (m + 1) ms ks' (x - k)
| otherwise   = p (m + 1) ms ks' (x - k) + p 0 (m : ms) ks x
results.author: _Matthew C. Russell_, Apr 25 2012
